summary: Suffering from insomnia, disturbed loner Travis Bickle (Robert De Niro) takes a job as a New York City cabbie, haunting the streets nightly, growing increasingly detached from reality as he dreams of cleaning up the filthy city. When Travis meets pretty campaign worker Betsy (Cybill Shepherd), he becomes obsessed with the idea of saving the world, first plotting to assassinate a presidential candidate, then directing his attentions toward rescuing 12-year-old prostitute Iris (Jodie Foster).

reviews.content: While the direction and acting are solid, the plot moves along very slowly and often it feels that not much of anything is going on. Overall though, a strong performance by Robert De Niro still makes Taxi Driver a decent watch.

"Taxi Driver" is a movie that focuses on the disturbing and dark dilemma of a pathological, lonely isolated man, Travis Bickle ( Robert De Niro ) and his hatred for the area he lives and works in. Due to his inability to sleep at night Travis takes a job driving a yellow cab around the squalor and underbelly of 1970's New York. It's here, particularly in the evenings, he experiences the crime, drugs and prostitution that are everyday life in and around the Big Apple. It's these experiences that intensifies Travis's unhinged thoughts as he begins to deteriorate mentally. 

In all this squaller and degradation Travis sees the angelic vision of a woman wearing a white dress. Drawn to the woman, Betsy ( Cybill Shepherd ) , who works as a campaigner for the Senator running for President, Travis makes contact and they end up going on a number of dates. However his mental state frightens her somewhat and she refuses to have anything more to do with him. After taking a fare ( Martin Scorsese himself ) who describes his desire to murder his wife and her lover, Travis is somewhat inspired to purchases a number of guns and embark on a strict training regime. One evening a young prostitute, Iris ( Jodie Foster ) tries to enter Travis's cab, unfortunately she is quickly stopped and forcibly removed by her pimp. Travis repeatedly sees the young girl and eventually pays the pimp to meet up with her. Travis, convinced that Iris is trying to escape her pimp,  tries to talk her into leaving the life of prostitution and either return to her parents or just get away to somewhere safe.

The final act sees the unstable Travis attempt to assassinate the Presidential candidate only to be foiled. As Travis makes his getaway he focuses on the young prostitute and after a violent bloodbath is heralded as a hero rather than a nut for saving the young girl and shooting a pimp and mafioso. Once Travis has recovered from the injuries sustained in the gun battle, he returns to his work as a cabbie. It's now we see the return of Betsy, unaware of Travis's attempt at assassination, she is in awe of his heroism and local celebrity status. "Taxi Driver" concludes with Travis driving away from Betsy and glaring maniacly at some unseen event. Unnervingly this final act shows that Travis's nightmare is not over but is destined to be repeated at some time later.

"Taxi Driver" - riskily watched for not knowing which time - turned out to be unexpectedly topical, fresh, still with the feeling that it is superbly realized and quite enjoyable - without being boring - to watch. Mainly due to the universal message: things are going wrong in the state, a disease is rolling over it, like a cancer, engulfing wider and wider circles of society, and it is the duty of the citizen to stand on the side of law, justice and other established values and express his opposition through vigorous action. The hero of the painting - a former Vietnam War veteran - opposes in a peculiar way. He takes a gun in his hands and intends to use it against - as it seems to him - the source of evil and decay, that is, the presidential candidate in the upcoming elections. A timely assassination thwarted by security causes Travis Bickle (the timeless Robert DeNiro!) to change the object of his "interest." He turns to his newfound acquaintances: the Hispanic pimp Sport (good ol' Harvey Keitel) and the place and people associated with the pimps. With one exception: not against the juvenile prostitute Iris (Jodie Foster's screen debut), whom he sympathized with and tried to help, including by drawing her away from her friends organizing the procedure and away from practicing "the world's oldest profession." 
The controversy is that in order to fix the world, the protagonist himself inflicts pain and suffering on others, and it makes little difference that his subjects are themselves caught up in evil and lawlessness and are actually guilty of it themselves. 
As Chicago Reader reviewer Jonathan Rosenbaum described the picture in January 2000 : "Perhaps the most formally thrilling - as well as the most morally and ideologically problematic - film in Martin Scorsese's career." It's hard to disagree with that opinion. _Witek Rusin

I think never has Taxi Driver been a more relevant movie to watch.   Martin Scorsese's disturbing look at the life of a troubled, disenfranchised, unreliable narrator is engaging and visceral and powerful.   The use of New York City as a secondary character in the movie is palpable and enhances the story and the viewing.   Almost 50 years later the performances of DeNiro, Keitel, and Foster really still resonate.   The film was so impactful that it created its own subgenera, of sorts.   While we can't help but be disgusted but what DeNiro's Travis Bickel has become we understand that the foundation upon which his dysfunctional responses are based are not misguided.   This character is often parodied and copied, but for his mannerisms and his classic lines; however, there is a depth and sympathetic quality to this character that only this Director and this actor could have brought out.   I love Jeff Bridges, the original choice for the film, but he would have been a very different Travis Bickel.  Watch this one, or watch it again.

Taxi Driver, while arguably Martin Scorsese's best film, is certainly the most pivotal movie in his development as a director.  Combining the gritty realism of the unpolished Mean Streets with his unique directorial style, Scorsese created what he would best be known for over the course of his career – violent, hard-nosed character studies.  In the case of Taxi Driver, the subject is Travis Bickle (Robert De Niro), a New York cabbie who descends into madness as the result of his perceived reality of the city.  Filled with solid performances (De Niro, Harvey Keitel, Jodie Foster, Peter Boyle, etc.), an ominous score from Bernard Herrmann, a remarkable script from Paul Schrader and Scorsese's distinct direction, Taxi Driver is a true classic.

What really stood out to me was the intensity of the movie and how New York is seen in a whole different aspect, how his mentality changed throughout the film. The rapists and prostitutes, how he views the city as filthy, as well as how Travis reacts to this situation. He is seen so suddenly wanting to help the young prostitute and save her at all costs. After being in the war, he felt impotent as if he had nothing to look forward to in life, though he began to view this opportunity of saving young Iris as a mission to make the world a lot less dirty in his mentality. I found it very intense how he resorted to violence very quickly, and even though his actions were very dark, he planned to do it all for a good cause. Even though he chose to save that young girl, his mindset was still set in a very dark and twisted way killing any who were in his way. You can see that his insatiable mentality was present the whole movie however it began shifting into a more heroic aspect. 
Overall, this movie was not a movie that I would further recommend. I think it had to do with the dark and unexpected plot of the movie, how it was also very oddly timed. Even though this movie was produced in 1976, a long time ago compared to 2022, the plot is not something that would be unbelievable in today's world, I do think that it is something that many would consider as relevant in today's time. A single aspect of the film that stuck with me would be the scene where Travis decides to take matters into his own hands and eliminate the people that hold Iris into her disgusting job. Showing up to the same hotel that he saw Iris not too long ago, he goes rampant, killing everyone that is involved in this, being the person that rents out the room and Matthew, the person that keeps her locked up in this job and is supposedly her lover. He also kills the person Matthew reports too, and a huge amount of bloodshed, whilst he also manages to take many gunshots himself. Once the bloodshed is done Travis immediately tries to shoot himself by sticking a gun below his jaw, and pulls the trigger to find that he used all the cartridges in his revolver. This part stuck to me because it makes it look like he wants no part in this world anymore, and after doing what he thinks is just he wants to leave it all with no hesitation. Then the police show up finding all the dead bodies, and finding Travis bleeding out, but smiling and pointing at his own head with a hand soaked in blood, signaling that he pulls the trigger on the imaginary gun multiple times. This stuck with me because the whole scene is kind of haunting, that a man smiles in the face of mass bloodshed, and smiles as he signals how badly he wants to take his own life.
My overall reaction to this movie is that it is enjoyable to a certain demographic. The production quality is pretty high and the plot is not completely bonkers, meaning it is understandable why Travis thinks the way he does and why he does the things he did. My issue is that this movie is now romanticized and I'm not sure how to feel about that.

An aspect of the film that really stood out to me the most was towards the end of the film the glorification of violence. Near the end of the film, we see Travis Bickle murder 3 men in cold blood in a shootout. Travis does this in attempt of saving Iris a 12-year-old prostitute from her so-called "protectors". Then instead of Travis dying in the shootout, we see him alive and labeled a local hero in the news clippings and the letter from Iris's parents. Labeling Travis a hero this makes him believe that they agree with his ideology of New York and how it needs to be cleaned up. Doing so this glorifies his aggressive/ violent behavior in his attempt to save Iris.

My overall reaction to the film was that it was an interesting topic and it is something I wouldn't have picked to watch on my own. I don't think I would recommend this film to viewers my age in the sense the film was oddly paced and wasn't very enjoyable for me. I do think that there are people who can enjoy this film but it depends on person to person. Although I didn't enjoy the film I still appreciate the quality and cinematography that went into this film and therefore give this film 2.5/5 stars.

One feature of the film that particularly struck out to me was how swiftly Travis' behavior changes in response to a particular situation. Travis was prompted to acquire a gun from a passenger who intended to murder his cheating wife. Travis isn't the kind of person who exhibits a violent trait, as was made clear at the beginning of the film. He will exert all of his effort and energy to get what he wants, with a good intention, such as going after a woman. But after being turned down by Betsy, he revealed his true colors. For most individuals, having a gun implies being able to defend oneself from harm, but Travis had other aims, such as plotting to assassinate presidential candidate Palestine. Then, when he saw a child being used for prostitution, his behavior abruptly changed once more, this time with a new goal in mind.

I wouldn't suggest the movie Taxi Driver to anyone who doesn't enjoy dark, twisted drama because it has a lot of sexual and violent content. Despite the fact that the movie seems to be popular, I believe it drifted too close to comedy. The movie's plot appears to be chaotic, cutting between many issues such as assassinating presidential candidate to rescuing a child prostitute. Despite being fairly nicely done, I found it difficult to follow. Instead of providing a different pathway that takes the audience down a different road, I would have preferred for the film to concentrate on one scene and expand from there.

What enthralls me the most about Taxi Driver is Robert DeNiro's portrayal of Travis, a man whose way of thinking is contingent on a worldview of shallowness. Travis suffers from a distinct mental cotton; he's been forgotten by wider society, an outcast with no meaningful connections. The tragedy of Travis as a character is his incapableness of recognizing his source of pain, which ultimately leads him to exercise his cowboy power fantasy. Throughout the film, it's clear how Travis perceives the citizens of New York: "Scum" "Venal" and "junkies". However, Travis is a man of contradictions, he recognizes the "poisons" within his life yet falters towards them time-and-time-again. Travis is depraved, sick, and just as lowly as those he lambasts and comes into conflict with during the film. Watching Travis regress into a culmination of hyper-masculine attributes and claim a sense of duty to wipe clean the "scum of new york" is peak poetic emotional torture. 

All in all, Taxi Driver is a cinematic classic and a must-watch for everyone who wants to get into films. Travis Bickle is a terrific character study of how a character struggles with mental illness, whose only means of exercising this sickness is through a hyper-masculine mission to reclaim a semblance of control. Taxi driver has solidified itself as one of my all-time favorite movies and one of the most influential films I've consumed. To avoid sounding like a broken record, I'll end this review by recommending you watch Taxi driver right now, I promise you won't regret it.

The story is unsettling but wonderfully told, and the script is brilliantly written. Scorcese also directs impeccably, while the acting is just excellent. Robert DeNiro gives one of his best performances, the whole film is worth watching just for his performance, that's how good it is, but that's not to dismiss Jodie Foster, Harvey Keitel and Cybill Sheppard in the supporting cast for they are just as good while Scorsese's own cameo is genuinely frightening. There you have it, another one of Scorsese's best with a brilliant atmosphere and mesmerising central performance. 10/10 Bethany Cox

It starts out with a troubled Vietnam veteran, Travis Bickle, who signs up as a late night cab driver as a hardworking job. The first 30 minutes of the movie establishes who our main character is: his thoughts towards the city, his unhealthy diet, his leisure interest. After signing up for the job, we soon perceive Travis's growing urge for violence. Travis suffers from an existential crisis that presents for us this troubled and displeased figure. My sensation for this movie exhibits with the brilliant dialogue, beautiful camera shots, and the flow of the story. Foremost of the movie's dialogue comes from Travis, narrating his thoughts that attribute to his disgust towards the urban decay of the city. The colorful cinematography that I think the movie nailed the best is spectacular. Especially when Travis is in the taxi. The camera's still, slow motion shots of the deranged streets put us into the vision of Travis. Lastly, the way the story moved was great. Every bad thing that has happened to Travis leads to his rampage at the end of the movie. Travis meets Betsy, but is left by her repulsion, which makes him angry. Travis witnesses countless acts of prostitution all over the city, making him a little more unhinged throughout the story. When Travis encounters Iris, a child prostitute, he's aware at how heinous that is, and he acts about it. I cannot stress this enough, Taxi Driver is a work of art that depicts the nuisances with modern society.

Travis Bickle is quite the icon of loneliness, alienated as he is by virtue of bewildering idiosyncrasies and destined to ever deepen his own resentment towards others through misguided preconceptions and fatal faux pas. Has cinema ever before given us this caliber of smoldering photography, dangerously detached and aloof music, and shockingly authentic dialogue bundled together into such a morbidly riveting package? Has the medium of film ever offered us a more stunningly ironic ending in conjunction with such a horrifyingly ominous and yet captivating buildup? In truth, many of these qualities emerge onto the screen as though projected directly through the filter of Travis Bickle's troubled and vulnerable soul, staining us all with queasy anticipation of his looming transgressions and rendering us strangely complicit in the process. As far as exercises in alienation go, "Taxi Driver" easily measures up among the most shocking and memorable of them, leaving an indelible impression on the viewer which is inevitably alluring and disturbing.

Martin Scorsese's psychological crime drama Taxi Driver (1976) remains one of my favorite films of all time as it perfectly captures disillusioned youth getting radicalized into violent vigilantes due to their PTSD, depression, boredom, isolation, loneliness, rejection, social awkwardness, poverty, rage, and frustrations.

Taxi Driver will disturb you with Scorsese's direction of a vicious and unforgiving world, while Robert De Niro will amaze you with his subtle and empathetic portrayal of emotionally volatile taxi driver Travis Bickle. De Niro finds Travis' frustrations and quiet thoughts as well as his bursts of violence and sudden misunderstandings. You completely buy De Niro being this insecure and odd young man turning into a murder happy vigilante. Taxi Driver is Martin Scorsese's greatest film with his captivating direction and Robert De Niro's best acting performance with a multitude of emotions being conveyed by De Niro.

Jodie Foster is outstanding in an early child actress supporting role as the child escort Iris Steensma. She's full of life and playfulness, while also conveying how hurt and uncomfortable Iris is with her life as a young lady of the night. Foster already displays her effortless charm, intense stares, adorable personality, nuanced understanding of her character, and deft versatility as the eager and traumatized Iris. Albert Brooks is unrecognizable as political campaign stooge and total square Tom. He's quite funny in Taxi Driver actually. Harvey Keitel is unsettling and fearsome as Iris' sleazy pimp Matthew "Sport" Higgins. Keitel's creepy words of endearment when he's trying to seduce and keep Iris under his power is truly revolting and effective acting.

Cybill Shepherd is quite lovely as the political rallying girl Betsy, who is too nice and normal for Travis' demented mind. She is perfectly aloof and intrigued by Travis' advances, which at first seem sweet and unorthodox, then perverse, unaware, and disgusting when Travis takes her to a porno theater for a movie. Peter Boyle's snarky and ignorant Wizard thinks he's so clever, which is why he comes across all too sleazy and uninformed. He gives Travis honest advice though that life is pointless so try to have fun and enjoy your lot in life.

Leonard Harris' too neat and tidy Senator Charles Palantine is omnipresent in Taxi Driver and when Travis meets him he's totally phony and disinterested until Travis' mad raving about New York's repugnant smells and filth horrify Palantine. I like how he never gives any real policies, just catchy slogans and empty promises like you'd expect from Paul Schrader's nihilistic script. You can see Robert De Niro's real wife at the time, Diahnne Abbott, cameo as the blunt adult film theater concession girl. I adore Martin Scorsese's cameo as the raving husband cab fare that makes Robert De Niro listen to his ramblings about his cheating wife he wants to kill. It's hilarious, but also gripping as Scorsese feels genuinely unhinged and sinister. 

Furthermore, Murray Moston is so eerie as Iris' "Time Keeper." Steven Prince's charismatic gun salesman is a riot to watch sell De Niro's Travis Bickle a briefcase full of arms. Martin Scorsese's real parents Catherine Scorsese and Charles Scorsese's even cameo as the voice of Iris' parents reading their letter to Travis at the end of Taxi Driver.

Scorsese's dreamy direction leaves me breathless as I feel doused in the smoky nights and neon lights of Scorsese's 1970's New York underbelly. Charles Rosen's art direction has characters glaring at nothing and New York's gritty look soaks into everything. Scorsese focuses on characters staring at each other for long pauses and holding on unnerving shots all over the city. Composer Bernard Herrmann's final film score is majestic, romantic, and forlorn with his moody jazz music to accompany Martin Scorsese's shadowy film noir directorial style.

Scorsese's direction is so striking and creative. He plays with characters appearing and disappearing out of shadows like demons or scenes fading in and out like Taxi Driver is just one big dream sequence. From cinematographer Michael Chapman's stunning shots that constantly focus on Travis leering at a girl or staring off into space, you are compelled by Scorsese's innovative direction in each mysterious scene. I love how Chapman has the camera on the side mirrors of the taxi cab or in the rearview mirror for all these neat perspectives of Travis. You never stop looking at New York, Travis, the girls, or this cruel, bleak world depicted in Taxi Driver.

For example, Scorsese's ambiguous ending leaves you to wonder what becomes of Travis Bickle the troubled taxi driver as his ideal life is realized or did he die or perhaps get arrested? Taxi Driver constantly fills my head with possible endings and lets you in on Travis' bad thoughts, so that you never let yourself wander your mind into dangerous or hurtful worlds. Taxi Driver wants people to connect and be decent to one another because Travis feels more like a cautionary tale and character study all in one brilliant picture.

Writer Paul Schrader's script brings out his social outcast tendencies, cynical view of society at large, and a tender empathy for his lead character Travis Bickle, who clearly suffers from PTSD from Vietnam, loneliness with no friends or girlfriend, rejection from every girl he knows, inability to express himself, poor wages with no mobility as a taxi driver that he only does to occupy himself away from his darker thoughts, and general sexual frustration with only attending porno theaters for movies. 

Travis Bickle's psychosis eventually leads to an attempted political assassination and street justice for a pimp and his cronies, but Schrader's beautiful script is intense, thoughtful, funny, scary, and shocking with every new dark corner he chooses for Travis to explore in his mind. Paul Schrader's story for Taxi Driver is excellent, but it is his pensive and escalating writing that engrosses you with Travis' inner monologues to himself in particular.

Editors Tom Rolf and Melvin Shapiro trick you with their sharp hard cuts and gentle dreamy editing style to lull you into a sense of security and strict narrative. I think you really get lost in Travis' mind as much as your own thoughts while watching Taxi Driver. It's an absorbing 114 minutes that feels like a brief moment. Taxi Driver really stays with you and I cannot stop thinking about it no matter how many times I revisit Scorsese's enigmatic film.

Herbert F. Mulligan's set decoration makes everywhere in New York look disgusting, dirty, and disturbing. Rick Alexander, Gordon Davidson, James Fritch, Sam Gemette, David M. Horton, Frank E. Warner, and Tex Rudloff's sound design is neat with screeching taxi cab tire wheels and shouting in the distance all around New York. You get loud gunshots piercing your head to quiet conversations being had in still moments around the city. 

In short, you get the noise of New York City as well as the painful isolation of a lonesome apartment or political crowd that is all too impersonal. Ruth Morley's costumes are phenomenal from Robert De Niro's mohawk and army jacket iconic aesthetic to Jodie Foster's playful child prostitute outfits and Cybill Shepherd's ladylike suits with style. Dick Smith's make-up gives De Niro a sleepless and unhinged look throughout Taxi Driver.

In conclusion, Taxi Driver is so genius because every direction, actor, actress, and crew member gave it their all with sterling decisions and cool choices. Taxi Driver will never leave you.

Taxi Driver Review
	Taxi Driver has a script that creates a very absorbing story, certain cinematography that's worth mentioning, and unforgettable acting  .	Taxi Driver is about a marine turned taxi driver named Travis Bickle who turns to violence in order to bring salvation to a troubled prostitute named Iris. 
	The writer of Taxi Driver, Paul Schrader brings Travis, the protagonist, into a captivating world that is authentically gloomy and sleazy .  Travis  enters a corrupt world that is full of: prostitutes, pimps, scumbags, and shady people which is ironic considering that he's living and working in the Big Apple  and not sin city. The environment is filled with violence including violence that Travis enforces and sex in brothels and pornographic films. There is a moment in the film where Travis talks to a presidential candidate named Charles Palatine about how dirty the city is and how it should be cleaned up. 
	The occasion where the cinematography is most radiantly used is at the opening of the film. New York City is seen through Travis's window and the lights and people look blurry. Travis is going to arrive in a very vague and suspicious world. There is another occasion where the cinematography is appropriately used for a very dramatic moment.   Travis is in a brothel laying on a couch after he's been shot in the neck. The cops arrive and there's a pan with the camera that shows a bird's eye view of Travis, the cops, and everyone else frozen.
	The actors in Taxi Driver give plenty of depth  with the characters they play  , particularly Robert Deniro as Travis Bickle. Robert Deniro gives depth to Travis, especially with his eyes. There are many shots of just Travis's eyes throughout the film and his eyes look suspicious and as if they don't know what to expect or who to trust. Iris is a character that you know has a ton of guilt, but Jodie Foster makes her have plenty of innocence as well once she gets into Travis's cab. 
	Taxi Driver has significant meaning with its: script, cinematography and acting.

Longtime collaborators Martin Scorsese and Robert DeNiro in one of their first entries from the 1970s.
Travis is a former marine now working as a taxi driver in the big city. He then sees a beautiful woman Betsy as a campaign associate. Inspired by her cause Travis then sets out to "clean" the world so to speak even so much as befriending and attempting to rescue a young prostitute on the streets. This is a nihilistic tale of isolation and reaction. 
He's cabbie by night but also secretly a vigilante. 
Travis begins to lose his touch with reality as he self-destructs.
Someone should become a person like other people. Maybe a huge rain should come down and clean up the streets full of scum. Loneliness is perhaps inevitable for some, it's what inhabits their whole world giving a messy look at the people surrounding them. 
Scorsese portrays a perfect example of an outsider that's unstable, introverted, socially inept, and psychologically imbalanced. Plus he lets us inhabit the hideousness of the filth of New York City setting. 
Many theories about how the film can range from a paranoid hallucination of a lonely man, a feminist work about the unstable ideals of masculinity, or an existential exploration of modernity. It's not 100% clear but that's how brilliant Scorsese is with his storytelling.
We see the perspective from inside the taxi as Travis himself sees the 'animals' of the world.
It's sort of like an extension of a drug induced dream or vision.
DeNiro is top of the line here in his early years, the smooth jazz score is fitting, there's some good philosophical and political commentary, and still holds one of the most iconic lines in cinema history.
Perhaps it's the lack of dogmatism that has the movie endure a continuing legacy for so long; there's always going to be judgement through eyes reflecting back like a taxi's rearview mirrors. One will always place themself behind the wheel and make their own view of Travis's mindset.

"Taxi Driver" follows Travis Bickle in his newly taken job as a New York cabbie. Due to his insomnia, he works long hours in the midst of the night growing disgusted with the city in which he lives. Along the way, he meets a couple of women that ultimately give him a motive for action. I'll be the first to say I think "Taxi Driver" is a bit overrated yet that isn't to say it's not a good film. Robert DeNiro plays New York City taxi driver Travis Bickle after the Vietnam War.  I think he may have been insane when he took the city, but as the movie unfolds he falls in love with a Presidential campaign worker Betsy (Cybill Shepherd).  Travis eventually works up the nerve to ask her for coffee and then on a date.  On the date, he takes her to a movie in one of the city's many porno theaters back in the mid-70s.  Of course, that ends that romance before it even got off the ground.  

In the meantime, Travis has run into an underage prostitute (Jodie Foster) and works to help her leave the business, which she does not seem to want to quit.  She seems to have turned her pimp (Harvey Keitel) into a father figure although he is nothing like a father.

I did not see that coming and for a movie that is this old I was surprised I had never heard how it ended.  It is quite a controversial ending and, if you watch it, you will learn why.

DeNiro, Shepherd and Foster are incredible and their acting is first rate in "Taxi Driver."  DeNiro plays the sad, lonely taxi driver so well that you believe he is that character.  It is crazy that he did not win a Best Actor Oscar for the performance.  Even the city of New York City plays a role in all this – a gritty, tough one.  I am so glad I finally watched this one.  I thought about this film for days after watching it.  That's a good sign.

Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver" is a bold, hard-hitting and unsettling masterpiece that sheds light on pertinent issues facing society today. With his fifth feature, legendary director Martin Scorsese crafted a mesmerizing film about vigilantism that holds up today as a classic. Using captivating cinematography, Scorsese draws viewers into the world of an alienated taxi driver in New York City. From intimate close-ups to anxiety-inducing panning shots, the cinematography keeps viewers immersed in the film's setting. It gives the film an ominous and foreboding atmosphere that captures the dark side of the city. In terms of writing, the film is elevated to another level by a superb screenplay. Paul Schrader's screenplay is sensational, and expertly uses voice-over narration to put viewers into the deranged mindset of the main character. It is hard to not admire the astonishing performances from the cast. Robert De Niro delivers one of the best performances of his career as Travis Bickle. With haunting expressions, he conveys the anger, loneliness and pent-up frustrations of a taxi driver that descends into insanity. The supporting cast, which includes the fantastic Jodi Foster, is also excellent and worthy of recognition. Although "Taxi Driver" is undeniably unforgettable, ultimately it is not a movie that is meant for everyone. The film tackles controversial topics such as vigilantism, gun violence and child prostitution that may upset some viewers. Nevertheless, fans of Martin Scorsese will definitely enjoy "Taxi Driver" and so will lovers of Cinema. Nearly 45 years after its release, the film remains ahead of its time with a powerful message that is relevant today. At a time when gun violence remains a pertinent issue in the world, it's a cautionary reminder of the dangers that vigilantes like Travis Bickle pose to society till this day.

Yet another perfect cooperation between Martin Scorsese & Robert De Niro. Watch this film for three times so far, and every time the familiar jazz comes up it never fails to please me. New York in the 1970s is in many ways a hellhole, filthy and crowded and stinks just like Travis' description, but it also shows it's own charm through Martin's camra. All those neon lights and sidewalks were ominously colourful, deflcting a certain aesthetic commonly seen in Martin's work. The character of Travis is also one of the most worth-studying in film history. He was, indeed, a walking contradiction, partly true and mostly non-fiction. As unpredictable and morally gray as he was, Travis somehow managed to let himself went far out of social borderline and still be relatable, he was a determined idealist without a purpose, a dreamer drenched from all the sleep and a tickling bomb constantly waiting to blow up. Taxi Driver as a film didn't give him a real solution or character growth, at the end, it simply puts him back into the old routine again, which is also understandable and realistic. There are few movies that can both show a disturbing fact and make it look beautiful, a perfect mess and a late night come-back. All the respect to Martin Scorsese & De Niro.

Taxi Driver is an absolute classic, this film is a must-see for everyone. De Niro's portrayal of an unstable and obsessive veteran is remarkable yet disturbing. The film is very well constructed following the downward spiral of an ex-marine. The film is dark, deranged, realistic, gritty, and unflinching. The acting in this film is tremendous on all parties involved, the music is intense and fits perfectly with the story and setting of the film using kind of a jazz feel to it. The film's climax is one of the best scenes in cinema which will definitely be implanted into the viewer's mind. The film also has a great ending which leaves the viewer wondering what really happened. As I mentioned earlier the acting in this film is great from all parties involved. Jodie Foster does a great job as Iris. I was very impressed with her performance throughout the film, usually, kid actors don't pull off a convincing character but every once in a while they really do. This is one of those instances. Harvey Keitel also does a great job as Sport, he delivers a great performance. Even though he has very little screentime he still leaves a great impression on the audience and creates a despicable, yet memorable character. The film also has many great scenes throughout such as the all-time classic "You talkin' to me?" scene, the opening scene where that taxi is emerging from the cloud and steam which covers it, the ending scene, especially the climax of the film, and even the dates that De Niro takes Cybill Shepherd's character Betsy on (Shepherd also does a tremendous job). Overall I would highly recommend this film to anyone but just a warning, it is a very gruesome film with many heavy themes and very heavy subject matter.

Martin Scorsese's Taxi Driver is a great character analysis and brought to life by a fantastic performance by Robert De Niro. Taxi Driver paints an extremely disturbing portrait -- we find ourselves understanding Travis' mindset. This is expert film making from Scorsese, cinematographer Michael Chapman, and the actors. Schrader's script, which was inspired by such diverse works as Dostoevsky's Notes From Underground and Harry Chapin's song, "Taxi," is a masterful psychological study, the depth of which can only fully be appreciated on repeat viewings. Even though more than 4 decades have passed since the film's release there is nothing dated about Taxi Driver. The message still rings as true as ever, and the characters are as shockingly believable as in the mid-seventies. The ending is a shocker to the psyche- Steeped in irony, the five-minute epilogue underscores the vagaries of fate. The media builds Travis into a hero, when, had he been a little quicker drawing his gun against Senator Palantine, he would have been reviled as an assassin. As the film closes, the misanthrope has been embraced as the model citizen.

The film is about a mentally unstable young man, Travis Bickle, played by Robert De Niro in a career-defining role, who projects his pent-up rage on the world around him in various forms. His hatred for New York City is deepened when Betsy, Cybill Shepherd, a woman whom he has had a brief affair with who works for a political campaign, breaks up with him cruelly. In response he directs his anger at her employee, political candidate Charles Palantine, planning to murder him in an expression of his rage. Jodie Foster's young prostitute, Iris, in a complicated relation with her pimp, Harvey Keitel, becomes a major character surprisingly late in the film but she too becomes a figure for Bickle to project his rage through.

As with every great Scorsese film, of which there are many, he is a able to capture an environment and a mood so accurately that you understand how Bickle feels about this â~dirty, stinking' city that he lives in. The beauty of Michael Chapman's cinematography shines through even as he captures the grime of the streets, the overly bright lights and the darkness of the world that Bickle inhabits. New York City is often a focus of Scorsese's work but unlike the later Gangs of New York (2002) this film feels very present in it's time period instead of looking hermetically sealed and heavily staged this film's design feels more natural and authentic linking to the dark, nihilistic tone of the film itself.

Bickle as a character is written as a complex and relatable figure by Paul Schrader but the story around him allows us to be horrified by his actions and the world around him as the film ends with his actions being glorified. We understand almost immediately that Bickle is mental and simmering with rage that he is willing to direct anywhere. One of the more heartbreaking scenes of the film features Bickle's voiceover as he complains of his disappointment with Betsy, "She's just like all the others." Bickle and Betsy are obviously not a good match and yet we want them to be together if only to see the lonely and obviously troubled Bickle, he can't sleep, experience some happiness. The loss of this anchoring figure causes Bickle to release his rage and although we understand by the end that Bickle would still have given into his violent tendencies at one point or another at this point in the film Schrader's screenplay causes us to believe that Betsy is a viable option for Bickle.

De Niro is fantastic as a crazed maniac hiding his inner psycho under a thin faÃ§ade of neuroses and awkward interactions punctuated by occasional moments of extreme confidence such as when he asks Betsy out. He appears perfectly cast here as he is able to appear innocent whilst also having murderous tendencies and he delivers his dialogue in a naturalistic but dramatic style and we feel for him and fear him at once. Foster is of course wonderful playing her role with precocious grace and is both a projection of Travis' fantasies and a fully realized character, largely due to Foster's brilliance. Cybill Shepherd, an actress whose abilities I doubt when playing â~serious' roles like The Lady Vanishes (1979), is well-cast in a role that requires her to look good and be shallow. The performances have all been written about ad nauseam but they are deserving of this honor.

Taxi Driver, rightfully considered one of the finest films ever made contains some of the best acting by Robert De Niro, fantastic direction by Martin Scorsese and one of the finest character study based screenplays by the great Robert Towne. Like Raging Bull, Taxi Driver features Robert De Niro in top form. From his first scene in Taxi Driver, De Niro is Travis Bickle, a 26-year old ex-Marine searching for work that will keep him up all night as a means of combating insomnia. At the outset, Travis is a lonely, disillusioned man who can still function within the "normal" constraints of society. As time passes, however, Travis becomes increasingly alienated from the world around him, spiraling into a state of dissociated delusion. He sees New York City as a place of urban decay populated by "animals" and "scum" that need to be swept away. De Niro's performance is so perfectly-tuned that we in the audience don't have a moment's doubt or disbelief about what's taking place in Travis' troubled mind. 9/10 (One of the finest character sketches in cinema history).

Strengths: There's a reason this film is considered a classic. Robert De Niro (Travis Bickle) gives a performance that isn't just among his best ever, but among the best in cinema history. It's that good. Travis is a portrait of the ugliest side of humanity and the acting is hauntingly great. Watching the character's evolution throughout the film is an experience that has rarely been matched. Though the movie doesn't have some big budget, it is shot in a way that makes the most of everything. It's gritty, just like the New York setting. Though Jodie Foster (Iris) isn't in the movie for long, she makes a lasting impression as the young prostitute. There are so many standout scenes. From the tense moments of wondering if Travis will go through with the shooting of the candidate to the bloodbath battle in the final minutes, it's intense and it all works. I appreciated how it told a story about PTSD without beating viewers over the head with it.

Weaknesses: I do think that the film is put over the top by De Niro's performance. Without it, the story would lend itself to being a very good movie, but not a great one. There are several scenes that feel long and somewhat unneeded. There are a handful of moments that seem a bit over the top. I also didn't really care for Cybill Shepherd (Betsy) and her performance.

Overall: It is a classic and it is a must see film because Robert De Niro gives an all-time great performance. Check it out purely to see some incredible acting, but the script is great and it's one of Scorsese's best.

A parceria de Scorsese e De Niro é uma das melhores que o cinema já presenciou, e aqui somos apresentados à um estudo intimista de um personagem perturbado por traumas passados e pela sua própria existência. Sentimos a solidão do protagonista e como ele enfrenta dificuldades em se socializar com as pessoas que parecem não compreende-lo pois a comunicação não é seu forte, enfrentando dificuldades para colocar seus sentimentos em palavras.
A atuação brilhante de De Niro tangência e transita muito bem pela insanidade do próprio protagonista e de suas reações encarando as insanidades que um taxista presencia nas noites de Nova Iorque, e como isso o afeta fazendo ele despertar um sentimento de repudio para com a cidade e com seus habitantes. Até que ele decide limpar a "sujeira" com suas próprias mãos, ajudando alguém que realmente precisava dele.
Mas um ator sozinho não consegue salvar um filme, que possui alguns pontos desnecessários em seu roteiro, repleto de cenas vazias e sem importância alguma pra trama que poderiam ser facilmente cortadas ou remodeladas para agregar algo à narrativa ou pelo menos entreter quem esta assistindo. O que foi todo aquela arco de tentativa de assassinato ? Ou para que a necessidade de um arco romântico tão grande, apenas pra mostrar algumas características do protagonista que poderiam ser facilmente exposta com menos.
Taxi Driver é uma representação majestosa do sentimento de solidão e desamparo em frente a uma multidão ou uma cidade individualista, com uma das melhores atuações de De Niro mas que encontra algumas problemas em sua narrativa que não conseguem ser contornados e que não nos recompensa mais a frente da história.

I just re-watched this recently due to boredom, and despite having seen it countless times, it unsurprisingly held up. There isn't much I can say about this movie that hasn't been said already. We're all familiar with the mohawk, the climactic bloodbath, and the famous quote, but there's more to the film than that. Taxi Driver isn't so much a movie but as an experience. Watching it is like experiencing a nightmare. It is one of the most disturbing films I have ever seen and the most disturbing aspect comes from just how relatable it is. 

We see the character of Travis Bickle in ourselves at our worst: when we are suffering, lonely, or pissed off. De Niro and Scorsese created not only one of the most iconic characters, but a living, breathing portrait of humanity that slowly crumbles under isolation and detachment in the neon hell of New York City. Travis Bickle is a modern day Sisyphus, doomed to wander the streets of hell as his life goes on over and over and over again. We watch as he slowly turns from a lost and traumatized veteran to a machine-like mass killer, and we are with him throughout the whole journey.

It doesn't have the high budget like most of Scorsese's later films, but Taxi Driver still succeeds on a technical level as well as a story level. Scorsese's direction and camerawork are on point; De Niro gives a raw, unflinching performance (not to mention the great supporting cast); Paul Schrader wrote one of the greatest screenplays of all time; the cinematography by Michael Chapman is hallucinogenic; and Bernard Herrmann delivered a fantastic jazz score which alternates between romantic and ominous. All these elements make for an engaging character study like no other.

Taxi Driver takes a lot of the last third of its plot from John Ford's masterpiece The Searchers and its nice to see Scorsese pay tribute to his idol without blatantly plagiarizing (I'm talking to you Tarantino).

Arguably Martin Scorsese's best film, writer Paul Schrader's best screenplay, and actor Robert De Niro's best performance. De Niro plays unstable Vietnam veteran Travis Bickle who the film follows down his rabbit hole of isolation, obsession, and eventual violent rage. The plot, as it is, has Bickle working nights as a NYC cab driver, becoming infatuated with pretty campaign worker, Cybill Shepherd, but when he sours that relationship due to his weird behavior, he becomes obsessed with saving pre-teen hooker Jodie Foster from her slimy pimp, Harvey Keitel. The plot could easily have become a simple Charles Bronson/grindhouse tale of urban vigilantism, but it's much more than that. Much has been written about "Taxi Driver" in terms of urban decay, isolation, desire, sex, misogyny, and as a critique of the media, all by others more eloquent than me, so I won't even try, but I will say that on a visceral level, the film is a ferociously disturbing piece of filmmaking. The audience is slowly drawn closer and closer to Bickle's madness, in a similar way to "Replusion" or "Peeping Tom.". The audience almost understands and sympathizes with his where his thinking is coming from and are found rooting for him against the even more despicable of characters during the film's disturbing finale. Scorsese has presented a New York City that truly is a brutal urban nightmare, but at the same time has created surreal hallucinatory vision of NYC that may only be Bickles perception of reality. Also of note, the film features memorable performances by Victor Argo, Peter Boyle, and Albert Brooks. Additionally, this was the final film scored by Bernard Herrmann and he delivers a memorably unrelenting and oppressive score that ranks among his finest. Overall, "Taxi Driver" is one of the finest pieces of cinema ever committed to celluloid, though due to it's profoundly disturbing nature will likely deny the film wide appeal.

The 1970s was a period in film that produced many timeless masterpieces, such as The Godfather, A Clockwork Orange, Apocalypse Now, and of course, Taxi Driver.  All of these films have something similar, as they delve into the deepest recesses of the human mind, and explore what makes people who they are and why they do what they do.  In Taxi Driver, we learn that the main character, Travis Bickle, is a Vietnam veteran who served in the marine corps during the war.  The movie starts off with him getting a job as a nighttime taxi driver in New York city, and his reasoning is that he drives around aimlessly at night anyways due to insomnia.  Travis lives a lonely life, interacting with no one except himself.  It's quickly learned that he has strong opinions about other people, mainly due to his job.  He sees the worst parts of New York, and drives around some disturbing people.  He constantly monologues how much he hates the "scum" of the city.  After a failed romantic attempt with his seemingly only hope to get something new, his mind begins deteriorating more and more due to isolation and the lowlifes that come out at night.  He then gets it into his mind that he has to save a twelve year old girl who's part of a prostitute ring, as he'd be doing something good while getting rid of the scum, and hopefully himself in the process.  This movie really goes into the problems of society, and how it can affect people that are already mentally unstable.  It brings you on a journey that leaves you feeling just as lonely and disturbed as Travis Bickle was during the film.

When Howard Beale in Network urged us all to put our heads out the window and scream "I'm as mad as hell, and I'm not going to take this anymore" in 1976, Travis Bickle pre-empted the call. Travis is one of cinema's most interesting characters, and one of its angriest, but he didn't have the eloquence of a Paddy Chayefsky script to help him voice his emotions, all he had was his violence. Of course outside of this anger, Network and Martin Scorsese's Taxi Driver have little in common. Taxi Driver, like so many wonderful films of its era (including Sidney Lumet's Network), got inside America's disillusioned mind, but it's no satire. Rather it's one of the most entirely disturbing and bleak portraits of a filthy society to have ever been posited.

Travis is America's sullen zeitgeist come to life. He's a disturbed man, an unstable ex marine suffering from insomnia who fills his long nights making money as a cab driver in New York's seediest streets. Scorsese keeps us in a state of constant unease with his New York, a city that is at once sweltering and chilly. You can sense its grime blackening your skin as we see Travis loathingly look out his car window to the walking and talking sewerage that has snuck out from under the streets. Travis sits atop that cinematic canon of disaffected young Americans that came out of the early New Hollywood era. Like Bonnie and Clyde before him, Travis's only discernible skill is his capacity for violence, a capacity which isn't truly unveiled until late in the film, but which presides over his thoughts and lingers in the back of our minds as we listen to his narration, installing the film with a constant dread. He's increasingly sickened by the filth that lines New York, disillusioned with what the world has become, and he's obsessed with cleansing it. This anger and unceasing dirtiness of Taxi Driver's world is noticeably enclosing. To see a city so unknowably filthy, through eyes so unknowably unstable and pained, holds us at a slight emotional distance, but makes for a nightmarish visceral plunge. 

What surprises most about Martin Scorsese's much admired psychodrama is how sad it is. For all his danger and anger, Travis Bickle's story is a tragedy. There's a goodness in him, but he doesn't know how to let it out. He's too isolated, too awkward and dumb to ever find the right words. There's a moment when Travis is writing a letter to his parents to wish them a happy trio of events. There's a sincerity in his intent, an affection, but he's unsure of the specifics and his handwriting is childish. His execution fails him as it does in his social life.

It's his relationship with the angelic campaign volunteer Betsy (Cybil Shepherd) that best highlights Travis's social ineptitude. He grows infatuated, he wants to be good to Betsy, but we never give them a chance because we know Travis is just too far removed. There's a much discussed shot in the film that augments the sadness of Travis's lonely story. As Travis is caught awkwardly on the phone trying to justify an embarrassment from one of their earlier dates, Scorsese slowly pans across to a long and empty hallway as if to shy away from Travis's pain. This is the moment that Scorsese felt he should turn away from; telling, given how unflinching the film is in its gruesome final act. When an opportunity for redemption offers itself up then, in the form of teenage prostitute Iris (a terrific Jodie Foster), we sense everything is at stake for Travis. His self assigned liberation mission is as much for him as it is for the young girl with her whole life ahead of her. He has an opportunity to make worth of himself and sweep away part of that filth that teases him so relentlessly.  

Robert De Niro's performance is tremendous, rendering that duplicity of sadness and scariness. He's at once vulnerable and threatening, but also brings a great enigma to Travis. Travis's mind mystifies, and it seems to hold us captive as we're aligned to his filters, seeing New York with the same contempt that he does. For all his instability, we can't help but feel Travis is right when says someone needs to clean this city up. 

Scorsese's classic may not involve us in the action as a film like Goodfellas does, but it is a world which owns us, which haunts us with its grime and dread. It's difficult to recall such a feeling of inundation watching a film, but that's what Scorsese does. He doesn't merely show us a world; he forces us to live in it.

What can be said about this film that hasn't been said already? As with all great films, Taxi Driver, arguably Scorsese's best work, is a multifaceted masterpiece, stuffed to the brim with philosophical concepts despite a minimalist plot and relatively short run-time. It's a gutsy piece too, both in terms of casting and topic, areas where the film veers into uncomfortable and challenging territory. The movie clearly has something to say about Vietnam, albeit in a more nuanced fashion than such a clear commentary as Apocalypse Now, which came three years later. Taxi Driver seems to be an urban representation of the chaos and moral upheaval after America's defeat and ideological failure in that war. Scorsese beautifully creates and narrates this disorder onto New York City, even as he clearly lays out an allusion to the state of the nation. Taxi Driver is also about a man, a veteran, struggling to come to terms with a city and country whose morality seems integrally compromised and illogical. There's a narrative here both for the man representing the tradition of the nation while also serving as a representative for a whole generation of traumatized young men who returned to a nation that had changed since they left, a nation that had become hostile to the very thing they fought for. At the same time, it's also a movie about the fundamental contrast really beginning to emerge in the 60's and 70's, that of the traditional white Christian background butting up against an increasingly diverse counterculture of ethnicity, religion and philosophical beliefs, all of which constitute the "ghetto" so often the target of white crusaders even today. DeNiro's character is at the crossroads here, a man who reviles this counterculture while also struggling to escape his own demons and understand Iris's (Jodie Foster) involvement in the very thing he despises. There's also an aspect of male fantasy here. DeNiro is a traditional white privileged male, in certain senses of the term. He often expects attention and understanding, despite his own neurotic and often delusional actions. He places expectations on Cybill Shepherd's Betsy, around whom he constructs a fantasy that becomes a point of obsession for him. He dreams of being a vigilante hero, endlessly toying with his weapons as a means of propping up his fragile masculinity. The entire sequence detailing his weapons is an acknowledgment of the American obsession with guns, both at home and in our wars abroad, with Scorsese not even needing to fire the weapons to show the absurdity of the whole act. DeNiro's character hopes to find purpose in violence and aggression while also struggling to find meaning in the traditional male 40 hour capitalist work week and daily grind. He considers himself to be a good guy and believes that his good nature entitles him to certain things. Scorsese is famous for his violence but Taxi Driver may be his most thoughtful film on the process. DeNiro spends an incredible amount of time imagining his role, daydreaming essentially and then crafting a swaggering persona built around his fantasy. Taxi Driver is also a deeply economic film, one of the early films to poke and prod at the supposed success of capitalistic, urban ideals. The films presents people who society expects to be happy and well adjusted. DeNiro's Travis, Betsy and Iris are all people who seem to have social roles laid out for them. Betsy adheres, DeNiro bounces back and forth while Iris bucks the system entirely. None of the characters are truly happy and Scorsese is one of the first in film to call attention to the decay of the "American Dream" and its subsequent promises. He also presents the desperation of people who clearly are at the end of their rope economically. For a film that took top prize at Cannes, Taxi Driver spends precious little time lingering on the lives of the white upper class, choosing instead to acknowledge that large sectors of the country simply were not able to advance socially or economically, a trend which continues to exasperate itself today. There's clearly a strong, prescient and complex examination of the increasing sexualization both of the female form and the increasingly young ages at which it occurs. This critical breakdown was eerily predictive, as we see younger and younger women featured in the fashion and movie industry as men demand more nubile objects of desire. Finally, there's a discussion here on mental illness, not in the more obvious sense detailed in later films more focused on the subject but in broader terms, the general insanity that results from urban crowding and decay, an issue that reflects itself statistically in the increased cases of mental illness in packed city environments. All of this exceptional undertones are tied together in a technically perfect film, where Scorsese uses a number of techniques to brilliant effect. There are the semi-single take shots, a sort of ancestor of the complex long takes filmmakers such as the modern visionary, Alejandro Iñárritu, have used to great critical acclaim. There is the incredible top down final action shot, which is a magnificent portrayal of the carnage DeNiro unleashes. Scorsese uses a diverse and groundbreaking toolbox here and he only helps himself with a truly exceptional cast. DeNiro sets the precedent for later method actors (Bale, Leto, McConaughey and others), completely transforming himself, losing weight and changing hairstyles while adapting seamlessly into the delusional gun carrier his character becomes. DeNiro perfectly portrays the obsession, the neurotic behavior and the social awkwardness without even uttering a single word. It's an incredible performance filled with world class gravitas. Almost equally impressive is Foster, a fantastically bold casting that also served as inspiration for other films (notably, The Professional and Natalie Portman's character). And Foster delivers despite limited screentime (not unlike a later film of hers where Anthony Hopkins pulled the same trick), transforming into a street savvy but ultimately beguiled young preteen stuck in a life she can't walk away from. It's moving and her brief moments show a poise few child actors have ever been able to bring to the table. Scorsese's brilliance in casting her cannot be overstated. Shepherd and an unrecognizable Keitel round out the primary cast and each shines in their limited roles. DeNiro's arc as the Taxi Driver is so perfect here. He wallows in his delusion until the very end but eventually comes to a semblance of peace, with Scorsese making the wise choice to have DeNiro part ways for good with Sybill's Betsy in a powerful closer to a powerful film. In the end, DeNiro opts (albeit reluctantly) for a last act of sacrifice on behalf of the young female Iris, choosing the relatively inglorious act of killing street gangsters as opposed to the public political and/or romantic killing he had in mind (Scorsese opts to leave much of that to the imagination of the viewer). This results not in DeNiro getting the girl or gaining a heroes reward from Iris's estranged parents but instead puts him right back in a cab with friends who barely seem to remember his act, choosing to leave DeNiro's ultimate fate somewhat unknown. In fact, Iris's story doesn't get a true conclusion either, another piece of artful ambiguity that young directors would do well to heed. Add in a soft jazz soundtrack (a musical style famous for its lack of resolution) and an ending that is part ambiguous, part curtain closer and you have yourself one of the greatest films of all time. In a world where minimalist film-making has become so trendy and neo-noir has become so common, it is impossible not to recognize Taxi Driver for its importance as an original inspiration to film, art and culture. A short list of great movies that directly utilized aspects of the film includes incredible works such as The Mechanic, LA Confidential, Fight Club, The Dark Knight, Blade Runner, The Guest, God Bless America, Something About Mary, The Professional and even literary works such as Watchmen, Sin City and V For Vendetta, with Watchmen's Rorschach in particular bearing eerie resemblance to DeNiro's Travis Bickle. It's an incredible list and those are just a few highlights. Taxi Driver deserves its place in the hall of incredible film and it deserves your viewing time again and time again.

Taxi Driver tells the unfortunate story of Travis Bickle, an ex-marine just returning from his time in Vietnam who struggles to cope with paranoid psychosis in 1970's New York.  Beginning and ending with trippy colors and stylish music from Bernard Hermann, Taxi Driver gets under your skin only when it wants to and in the most in opportune times.  It succeeds in giving you the uncomfortable feeling and anguish most associated with noir and it does so in fashion.

Bickle's skepticism and cynical view of New York City is perfectly portrayed by De Niro as we root for him the entire length of the movie.  All of this tends to get him into trouble, but we don't care, because we are so sucked into Bickle's every move and every word that we don't tend to notice just how insane he has become.  Of course, the film is iconic for its famous "You talkin to me?" line and its brutally violent climax, but its Scorsese's direction of De Niro's performance I will remember most.

With this film comes plenty of questions as to whether or not any of it is actually real or not, which in most cases is valid.  But I don't really care one way or another.  No matter what, this is a tragic tale of a man lost in a world that he doesn't understand and a world that doesn't understand him.  Whether or not the engaging narration is misleading is up to interpretation, but I just know that it's a wonderfully intricate story of a troubled Taxi Driver.  If De Niro's encapsulating performance isn't enough for you than perhaps Scorsese's brilliant direction and Bernard Hermann's hauntingly beautiful and stylish score will be.  Taxi Driver is a masterpiece.

"Taxi Driver's" you talking to me? soundbite has perpetuated the iconic movie quote walls for what feels like a century.  Those familiar with it do their best tough-guy Robert De Niro impression whenever the film is brought up, only to laugh along with their listening companions as they go back to small chatter seconds later.  But few remember the improbably sadness that comes with the line.  The scene in which it appears spotlights a shirtless De Niro, gun in hand, facing the mirror like a narcissistic gangster, exceptionally vulnerable.  He is asking no one and will probably never have the chance to ask anyone; a socially stunted outcast his entire life, he has never been important enough to be talked to.  He always has to start the conversation, with the other party often walking away to converse with someone more ... normal.
	"Taxi Driver" is a tremendously melancholy film, one of loneliness, despair, and the unforgettable consideration as to if simply being alive is enough of a reason to live if no one wants you.  The movies, too often, surround themselves with attractive people speaking attractively, doing attractive things in attractive places.  But here, those parties are looked at from afar, glamorized but untouchable.  It is, instead, about the loners who want to be part of that in-crowd but don't have the social skills, the looks, the personalities, to be included in anything resembling high culture.  
	The man mirroring the emptiness we can often times feel in this difficult game of life is the iconic Travis Bickle (De Niro), an insomniac taxi driver who works twelve hour shifts and who cannot seem to function living in a post-Vietnam world.  He is suffering from the aftermaths of fighting, yet it seems he has always been a persnickety wallflower - his gloom has increased in result to his past traumas.  He is passive, mannered, and unable to form real relationships; but the more a situation aggravates him, the more dangerously hot-headed he becomes.  His only stability comes from writing letters to his parents, whose existence we question.
	Two women provide the heart of the film and change Travis's life for the better or for the worse, depending on how you look at them.  The first is Betsy (Cybill Shepherd), a cool, blonde campaign worker who becomes the target of Travis's romantic obsessions.  He sees her as the perfect woman, and, unwilling to let her slip into the arms of a co-worker (Albert Brooks) he suspects has sensual interest in her, he asks her out.  His slight good looks prompt her to push past his eccentricities, but when a date leads to a pornographic theater, a place Travis has no idea is insulting to take the time to visit, she immediately loses interest.  In one of the most disturbing scenes of the film, she rejects him over the phone, the camera panning to an empty hallway to distort the pain Travis so deeply feels.  No one is crying with you, the shot says.  It's chilling.
	His misanthropy toward the world is soon amplified, and, with violence in his heart growing, he stumbles upon twelve-year-old hooker Iris (Jodie Foster), who has run away from home and works under the watchful eye of her pimp, Sport (Harvey Keitel).  She doesn't want to be saved - she likes sex work - but Travis sees the tragedy and reacts excessively.
	In "Taxi Driver," the supporting actors, though important, are white noise.  We see through Travis's eyes so vividly that it is as if everyone is behind a sheet of bulletproof glass.  Consider the way Scorsese takes the time to act as voyeur to Betsy and her work friend's conversations, which are so obnoxiously witty that they only heighten Travis's simultaneous dislike and envy of those successful and accepted in life.  Consider how Iris does not want to leave the ghetto streets of New York, and how Scorsese photographs the intense shootout that leads to her "freedom" in a subtle red that magnifies just how unjustified Travis's gunning is.  The latter tells himself that it's an act of good, but he, deep down, knows that all he really wants is an excuse to inflict violence on the "scum" he so outrightly hates.
	Travis Bickle was voted as one of the American Film Institute's most seminal villains, but I don't see him as one - he is neither a hero nor a foe, rather an embodiment of a detached party of humanity.  He was not bred to be homicidal; he was made that way, through tireless rejection and an array of relentless cold shoulders.  He has grown to despise the world because of what he perceives it has done to him, and what we witness throughout "Taxi Driver" is his eventual inability to keep his anger, his sadness, hidden anymore.  
	Scorsese brilliantly elevates his disconnection by keeping scenes of conversation flat and in-the-moment, with interludes that depict Travis in his taxi accompanied by lonely jazz music and a floating aesthetic that further disengages him with the life that is buzzing about around him.  Friends, family, lovers, roam the streets.  To Travis, they are alien - he only knows what it's like to be alone with his thoughts, stewing and stewing until they're overcooked, delusional.
	De Niro's untouchable performance is a masterwork in understatement - he is often silent, quiet in the presence of others, alive when by himself.  Even when in the public eye, he still can't help but remain to be his own best friend.  Would-be friends are a fog.  De Niro does so much with expression, with vocal delivery; little things expand Travis's standing as a man alone on Earth - he is almost a higher being, looking down at the world and unsure what to think of it.  As Travis, De Niro is as sympathetic as he is frightening.  We pity his despair, but we also are unsure of when he's going to snap.  This is one of the greatest performances in the history of film.  Foster, a teenage heavyweight, is equally remarkable as an impressionable youth whose life goes in a completely different direction than she would have thought thanks to the film's titular taxi driver.
	Almost forty years later, "Taxi Driver" still stands as the exemplary Scorsese movie - in-control, unpredictable, observant, and slightly savage.  It is very much a New York film, though it doesn't romanticize its "big city" tropes; it accentuates the idea that someone, in the blink of an eye, can get lost in this world, and that living in the shadows of society is no home.  Here is one of the finest depictions of alienation in cinema, next to "Red Desert" and to "Blue." Whether we like it or not, we have all experienced what Travis has.  Just maybe not so violently.

I was way too young when my father took me to see this movie upon what must have been it's second "round" at our then local drive-in. It would be a number of years later at Cambridge's Historic Brattle cinema that I would see it agin in a fading print. 

Martin Scorsese and Paul Schrader capture a Manhattan long since gone. It is like a "time capsule" piece of it's day. It also might be the first film that truly presented audiences with what full fits the definition of "Anti-Hero." 

This film firmly cemented Robert Di Niro as the actor of his generation. As well as permanently imprinting Jodi Foster into American Pop Culture. Michael Chapman's breathtaking cinematography and Bernard Herrmann's musical score are both essential to this iconic film's success. But for the most part, this is Di Niro's film. 

Only within context of NYC's perversity of 42nd Street and surrounding drug/sex culture, along with 1970's confused ideas around "Sexual Liberation" and the political paranoia of this time would we be able to actually view "Travis Bickle" as a "hero." 

We know that he is walking a very thin line between sanity and sociopathic danger, but it is impossible not to feel for him. His insanity often feels like the only sane aspect of the world in which he drives and navigates. Attempts at connections are tainted by his inability to form a clear understanding of anything going on around him. 

This is mid-1970's film is an incredibly insightful depiction of dystopia and insanity. 

While the once shockingly brutal special effects have aged poorly, there can be no denying the power and importance of this cinematic dark vision. The fact that we have now become far too sophisticated when it comes to "realistic" gore is only a further example of wether we have moved "forward" or interestingly "backward" in the passing of time. The dated special effects have taken on an almost unintended idea of surrealism and allegory. 

The final minute of this film remains one of the most surprising and disturbing in cinematic history. You have to watch closely just before the credits begin to roll. If you blink, you might miss it. 

But the reality of Travis Bickle remains firmly in place for tragic implications that the people within his world can grasp. He is not just a misfit or loner. Travis Bickle is insane. And most disturbing, this film is even more relevant in the 21st Century than it was 40 years ago.
